intro: Cyrilla megaphylla, commonly known as the large-leafed cyrilla, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Ericaceae family, which includes heaths and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and showy white or pink flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, acidic soils and is often found in wetlands or along stream banks. Its leaves are large, ovate, and have a leathery texture, while its fruits are small, capsule-like structures that release seeds when mature. Cyrilla megaphylla plays an important ecological role in its native habitat by providing food and shelter for various wildlife species.
